rows.COMPLIANCE PROTOCOL — TWO-KEY STATE TRAN: The Librarian shouldn't grade their own homework. Conductor counter-signs state transitions. Two-key system.
THE PROBLEM
The Librarian routes work AND enforces process compliance. That's a conflict.
They have incentive to keep things moving, not to slow things down for compliance.
A standalone Compliance Manager is overhead the pre-funding model can't afford.
Solution: two-key system. Librarian routes and locks. Conductor confirms the transition was legitimate.
Neither can do it alone. Zero additional headcount. Just a procedural check.
TWO-KEY TRANSITION TABLE
Transition
T01: NULL→DRAFT
rows.col_3: Librarian (confirms P-tab exists and is filed)
rows.col_4: P-tab is structurally complete and filed in correct location
rows.col_5: TUP stays in NULL. Nilo must complete P-tab.

rows.COMPLIANCE PROTOCOL — TWO-KEY STATE TRAN: T12: DRAFT→PRODUCTION
rows.col_3: Librarian (confirms PM has tab slice and tool access)
rows.col_4: PM's Google Drive folder is populated. Dependencies are met (PRE-01 etc).
rows.col_5: Cluster stays in DRAFT. Conductor resolves access/dependency issue.

rows.COMPLIANCE PROTOCOL — TWO-KEY STATE TRAN: T23: PRODUCTION→INTERNAL_REVIEW
rows.col_4: All C-tabs listed in P-tab are present with content. No empty tabs submitted.
rows.col_5: TUP stays in PRODUCTION. PM must complete missing tabs.

rows.COMPLIANCE PROTOCOL — TWO-KEY STATE TRAN: T34: INTERNAL_REVIEW→EXPERT_REVIEW
rows.col_3: Conductor (confirms not blocking other clusters + expert assigned)
rows.col_4: Expert Reviewer is assigned, independent (no conflicts), and available within timeline.
rows.col_5: TUP stays in INTERNAL_REVIEW. Conductor resolves scheduling/independence issue.

rows.COMPLIANCE PROTOCOL — TWO-KEY STATE TRAN: T45: EXPERT_REVIEW→LOCKED
rows.col_3: Librarian (confirms lock) + Conductor (confirms grade inflation check passed)
rows.col_4: Grade is recorded with per-tab notes. Review time ≥ minimum threshold. Grade inflation defense not triggered.
rows.col_5: TUP stays in EXPERT_REVIEW. If inflation flagged: secondary review triggered.

rows.COMPLIANCE PROTOCOL — TWO-KEY STATE TRAN: TAMEND: LOCKED→EXPERT_REVIEW
rows.col_3: Librarian (confirms justification filed) + Conductor (confirms downstream impact assessed)
rows.col_4: Written justification exists. Impact on dependent TUPs documented.
rows.col_5: Lock holds. Amendment denied. Nilo can override but it's logged.

rows.COMPLIANCE PROTOCOL — TWO-KEY STATE TRAN: COMPLIANCE ROLES (pre-funding vs post-funding)
Phase
Pre-funding (imagination)
rows.col_5: Two-key transitions. Override = Nilo only, logged.

rows.COMPLIANCE PROTOCOL — TWO-KEY STATE TRAN: Post-funding (implementation)
rows.col_3: Trustee (fiduciary oversight, AU permission on everything)
rows.col_4: Grade Inflation Defense + Trustee audit rights
rows.col_5: Two-key + Trustee audit trail. Trustee can pause operations on threshold breach.

rows.COMPLIANCE PROTOCOL — TWO-KEY STATE TRAN: WHAT HAPPENED TO THE COMPLIANCE MANAGER?
The Vicioso/DAO model has a Compliance Manager who assesses and grades process adherence.
In the IonWave implementation, that function is distributed:
— Process compliance during production → Librarian + Conductor two-key system
— Grade quality → Grade Inflation Defense structural mechanisms
— Fiduciary compliance post-funding → Trustee with AU permission
— State machine integrity → Two-key transitions + logged overrides
No standalone CM role because the protocol IS the compliance mechanism.
If transitions require guard conditions, and two people must confirm them, that's compliance by design.
A dedicated CM might make sense at scale (multiple Trades running simultaneously). For IonWave v1, the distributed model is sufficient.
NOTE: CONDUCTOR SCOPE EXPANSION

Conductor now also builds ops site + Shopify storefront using AI tools. This adds to Conductor workload but eliminates Product Person role (saves 2-4% equity). Conductor's two-key counter-sign duties remain unchanged — site building is a separate workstream.
